     285             :   /**
     286             :    * returns true if this string overlaps with the given string fragment.
     287             :    */
     288             :   bool IsDependentOn(const char_type* aStart, const char_type* aEnd) const
     289             :   {
     290             :     /**
     291             :      * if it _isn't_ the case that one fragment starts after the other ends,
     292             :      * or ends before the other starts, then, they conflict:
     293             :      *
     294             :      *   !(f2.begin >= f1.aEnd || f2.aEnd <= f1.begin)
     295             :      *
     296             :      * Simplified, that gives us:
     297             :      */
     298             :     return (aStart < (mData + mLength) && aEnd > mData);
     299             :   }
     300             : 
     301             : protected:
     302             :   nsTStringRepr_CharT() = delete; // Never instantiate directly
     303             : 
     304             :   constexpr
     305             :   nsTStringRepr_CharT(char_type* aData, size_type aLength, uint32_t aFlags)
     306             :     : mData(aData)
     307             :     , mLength(aLength)
     308     2338128 :     , mFlags(aFlags)
     309             :   {
     310             :   }
     311             : 
     312             :   char_type*  mData;
     313             :   size_type   mLength;
     314             :   uint32_t    mFlags;
     315             : 
     316             : public:
     317             :   // mFlags is a bitwise combination of the following flags.  the meaning
     318             :   // and interpretation of these flags is an implementation detail.
     319             :   //
     320             :   // NOTE: these flags are declared public _only_ for convenience inside
     321             :   // the string implementation.
     322             : 
     323             :   enum
     324             :   {
     325             :     F_NONE         = 0,       // no flags
     326             : 
     327             :     // data flags are in the lower 16-bits
     328             :     F_TERMINATED   = 1 << 0,  // IsTerminated returns true
     329             :     F_VOIDED       = 1 << 1,  // IsVoid returns true
     330             :     F_SHARED       = 1 << 2,  // mData points to a heap-allocated, shared buffer
     331             :     F_OWNED        = 1 << 3,  // mData points to a heap-allocated, raw buffer
     332             :     F_FIXED        = 1 << 4,  // mData points to a fixed-size writable, dependent buffer
     333             :     F_LITERAL      = 1 << 5,  // mData points to a string literal; F_TERMINATED will also be set
     334             : 
     335             :     // class flags are in the upper 16-bits
     336             :     F_CLASS_FIXED  = 1 << 16   // indicates that |this| is of type nsTFixedString
     337             :   };
     338             : 
     339             :   //
     340             :   // Some terminology:
     341             :   //
     342             :   //   "dependent buffer"    A dependent buffer is one that the string class
     343             :   //                         does not own.  The string class relies on some
     344             :   //                         external code to ensure the lifetime of the
     345             :   //                         dependent buffer.
     346             :   //
     347             :   //   "shared buffer"       A shared buffer is one that the string class
     348             :   //                         allocates.  When it allocates a shared string
     349             :   //                         buffer, it allocates some additional space at
     350             :   //                         the beginning of the buffer for additional
     351             :   //                         fields, including a reference count and a
     352             :   //                         buffer length.  See nsStringHeader.
     353             :   //
     354             :   //   "adopted buffer"      An adopted buffer is a raw string buffer
     355             :   //                         allocated on the heap (using moz_xmalloc)
     356             :   //                         of which the string class subsumes ownership.
     357             :   //
     358             :   // Some comments about the string flags:
     359             :   //
     360             :   //   F_SHARED, F_OWNED, and F_FIXED are all mutually exlusive.  They
     361             :   //   indicate the allocation type of mData.  If none of these flags
     362             :   //   are set, then the string buffer is dependent.
     363             :   //
     364             :   //   F_SHARED, F_OWNED, or F_FIXED imply F_TERMINATED.  This is because
     365             :   //   the string classes always allocate null-terminated buffers, and
     366             :   //   non-terminated substrings are always dependent.
     367             :   //
     368             :   //   F_VOIDED implies F_TERMINATED, and moreover it implies that mData
     369             :   //   points to char_traits::sEmptyBuffer.  Therefore, F_VOIDED is
     370             :   //   mutually exclusive with F_SHARED, F_OWNED, and F_FIXED.
     371             :   //
     372             : };
     373             : 
     374             : } // namespace detail
     375             : } // namespace mozilla
     376             : 
     377             : /**
     378             :  * nsTSubstring is an abstract string class. From an API perspective, this
     379             :  * class is the root of the string class hierarchy. It represents a single
     380             :  * contiguous array of characters, which may or may not be null-terminated.
     381             :  * This type is not instantiated directly. A sub-class is instantiated
     382             :  * instead. For example, see nsTString.

     384             :  * NAMES:
